facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 233 of 1962 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 233 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated August 2, 1961 of Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 814 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 2, 1961, of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 814 of 1961.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by SUBBA RAO, J. on July 30, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. July 30. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO, J.-

facts.text: Dispute regarding election to Panchayat of Byappanahalli from its first constituency in State of Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave arises out of a dispute in respect of the election to the Panchayat of Byappanahalli, from its first companystituency, in the State of Mysore.

facts.text: Notification of election on 6-2-1960.

anchor.surface_text: Notification of election.6-2-1960

facts.text: Date by which candidates had to file nomination papers: 16-3-1960.

anchor.surface_text: Date by which candidates had to file numberination papers.16-3-1960

facts.text: Date of scrutiny of nomination papers: 18-3-1960.

anchor.surface_text: Date of the scrutiny of numberina- tion papers18-3-1960

facts.text: Poll held on 13-4-1960.
Declaration of result on 14-4-1960.

anchor.surface_text: Peolaration of result14.4-1960

facts.text: Appellant and five others filed nomination papers within prescribed date.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and five others filed their numberination papers within the prescribed date.

facts.text: Polling took place on April 13, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The polling took place on the scheduled date, namely April 13, 1960.

facts.text: Appellant secured 169 votes.

anchor.surface_text: The candidates secured votes as mentioned under Appellant 169 votes

facts.text: Respondent 2 secured 158 votes.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent 2 158 votes

facts.text: Respondent 1 secured 128 votes.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent 1 128 votes

facts.text: Respondent 3 secured 115 votes.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent 3115 votes

facts.text: Respondent 4 secured 38 votes.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent 438 votes

facts.text: Respondent 5 secured 46 votes.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent 546 votes

facts.text: Appellant and Respondent 2 declared elected.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and respondent 2 were duly declared elected to the Panchayat.

facts.text: Respondent 1 filed election petition under s.13 of Mysore Village Panchayats and Local Boards Act, 1959 in Court of Second Munsiff, Bangalore.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent 1 filed an election petition under s.13 of the Mysore Village Panchayats and Local Boards Act, 1959  Mysore Act No. 10 of 1959  hereinafter called the Act, in the Court, of the Second Munsiff, Bangalore,

facts.text: Election petition sought declaration that appellant was not duly elected and Respondent 1 was duly elected.

anchor.surface_text: for a declaration, that the appellant was number duly elected and for a further declaration that the first respondent was duly elected.

facts.text: Respondent 1 claimed appellant's name not in authenticated list of voters on nomination filing date.

anchor.surface_text: that on the date, fixed for filing of numberinations the appellants name was number in the authenticated list of voters published under r. 3, cl.  5  of the Mysore Panchayats

facts.text: Respondent 1 claimed appellant not ordinarily resident of Byappanahalli.

anchor.surface_text: and, therefore, he was number entitled to file his numberination. It was his further case that the appellant was number ordinarily a resident of Byappanahalli

facts.text: Munsiff held appellant ordinarily resident of village and qualified for electoral roll.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Munsiff held on the second point that the appellant was ordinarily a resident of the said village and was, therefore, qualified to be included in the electoral roll of the Panchayat,

facts.text: Munsiff found appellant's name not included in authenticated list of voters.

anchor.surface_text: but he came to the companyclusion that his name was number included in the authenticated list of voters of the said Panchayat.

facts.text: Munsiff set aside appellant's election and declared Respondent 1 elected.

anchor.surface_text: On that finding, he set aside the election of the appellant and declared the first respondent, who secured the next highest number of votes, to have been duly elected in his place.

facts.text: High Court disagreed with Munsiff's reasoning but agreed with conclusion that appellant's election to be set aside.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the learned Judges of the High Court, after numbericing the finding of the Munsiff to the effect that the appellants name was number included in the authenticated list of voters for the Panchayat, observed that they did number agree with the reasoning given by the learned Munsiff, but they agreed with his companyclusion on the basis of a different reasoning.

facts.text: High Court held appellant's name inclusion in legislative electoral roll violated r.26 of Representation of the People Rules, 1956, and was void.

anchor.surface_text: They held that though the name of the appellant was included before- the prescribed date in the electoral roll of the legislative companystituency under s. 23 of the Representation of the People Act, 1950, it was so included in direct violation of r. 26 of the Representation of the People Rules, 1956, arid that, therefore, the said inclusion was void.

facts.text: Respondents did not appear in Supreme Court appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents did number appear.

facts.text: First respondent admitted in election petition that appellant's name was included in authenticated list on nomination date.

anchor.surface_text: But a persual of the election petition shows that the first respondent accepted in his petition that the name of the appellant was included in the said authenticated list on the date when be filed his numberination paper.

facts.text: Appellant's name included in electoral roll of Mysore Legislative Assembly before nomination date.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon case that the name of appellant was included in the electoral roll of the Mysore legislative Assembly before the date prescribed for filing of numberination papers.

facts.text: Application filed before Electoral Registration Officer for inclusion of appellant's name in electoral roll.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that an application was filed before the registration officer for the inclusion of the appellants name in the electoral roll

facts.text: Electoral Registration Officer did not follow procedure in r.26 (posting application and inviting objections).

anchor.surface_text: it is also companymon case that the electoral registration officer did number follow the procedure prescribed in r.26 relating to the posting of the application in a companyspicuous place and inviting objections to such application.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 2, 1961, of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 814 of 1961.
of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 814 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Section 9 of the Act reads The electoral roll of the Mysore legislative Assembly for the time being in force for such part of the companystituency of the Assembly as is included in any Panchayat companystituency shall, for the purpose of this Act, be deemed to be the list of voters for such Panchayat companystit- uency.

concepts.interpretation: Electoral roll of Assembly constituency deemed to be list of voters for Panchayat; Secretary to maintain authenticated copy.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 says Every person whose name is in the list of voters of any Panchayat companystituency shall, unless disqualified under this Act or under any other law for the time being in force, be qualified to be elected as a member of the Panchayat .

concepts.interpretation: Person in voters list qualified to stand for election unless disqualified under Act or other law.

anchor.surface_text: Section 23 of the Representa- tion of the People Act, 1950, reads Any parson whose name is number included in the electoral roll of a companystituency may apply in the manner hereinafter provided for the inclusion of his name in that roll.

concepts.interpretation: Allows application for inclusion in electoral roll.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ough his order may be liable to be set aside in appeal or by resorting to any other appropriate remedy. The Act proceeds on the basis that the voters

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 23, Representation of the People Act, 1950
concepts.unlisted_description: Application for inclusion in electoral roll.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 26 of the Representation of the People  preparation of Electoral Rolls  Rules, 1956, says Every application under sub-section  i  of section 23 shall be made in duplicate in Form 4  Part 1  and shall be accompanied-  a  where it is to the chief electoral officer, by a fee of ten rupees, and  b  where it is to the electoral registration officer, by a fee of one rupee.

concepts.interpretation: Prescribes procedure for application including posting notice and inviting objections within 7 days.
concepts.unlisted_label: Rule 26, Representation of the People (Preparation of Electoral Rolls) Rules, 1956
concepts.unlisted_description: Procedure for processing applications for inclusion in electoral roll.

anchor.surface_text: Section 24 of the Representation of the People Act, 1950, provides An appeal shall lie within such time and in such manner as may be prescribed-  a  to the chief electoral officer, from any order of the electoral registration officer under section 22 or section 23,

concepts.interpretation: Provides for appeals from registration officer's orders.
concepts.unlisted_label: Section 24, Representation of the People Act, 1950
concepts.unlisted_description: Appellate remedy against electoral inclusion orders.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 27 of the Representation of the People  preparation of Electoral Rolls  Rules,1956, prescribes the procedure for preferring appeals.

concepts.unlisted_label: Rule 27, Representation of the People (Preparation of Electoral Rolls) Rules, 1956

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 30 of the Representation of the People Act,1950, numbercivil companyrt shall have jurisdiction to question the legality of any action taken by, or under the authority of, the electoral registration officer.

concepts.interpretation: Bars civil courts from questioning actions of electoral registration officer; to be rectified only by appeal or prescribed remedy.
concepts.unlisted_label: Section 30, Representation of the People Act, 1950
concepts.unlisted_description: Ouster of civil court jurisdiction over electoral registration actions.

anchor.surface_text: We find it difficult to say that the action of the electoral registration officer is a nullity. He has admittedly jurisdiction to entertain the application for inclusion of the appellants name in the electoral roll and take such action as he deems fit. The number-compliance with the procedure prescribed does number affect his jurisdiction, though it may render his action illegal.

concepts.interpretation: Procedural non-compliance renders action illegal but not a nullity or non est if officer has jurisdiction; liable to be set aside only in appeal or other remedy.
concepts.unlisted_label: Procedural Irregularity Not Rendering Act Nullity
concepts.unlisted_description: Distinction between jurisdictional defect and procedural illegality in administrative actions.

anchor.surface_text: The Act proceeds on the basis that the voters list is final for the purpose of election. Under s. 10 of the Act, every person whose name is in the list of voters of any Panchayat companystituency shall, unless disqualified under this Act or under any other any other law for the time being in force, be qualified to be elected as a member of the Panchayat.

concepts.interpretation: Electoral roll final for determining qualification to contest; cannot be challenged in election petition for illegal inclusion.
concepts.unlisted_description: Voters list conclusive for election purposes absent disqualification.

anchor.surface_text: The Act companyfers a special jurisdiction on the Munsif to set aside an election, and he can do so only for the reasons mentioned in s. 13  3  of the Act. The relevant provision is in s. 13- 3   A   d   i  which relates to the improper acceptance of any numberination.

concepts.interpretation: Election court has limited jurisdiction confined to statutory grounds; no power to question validity of voters list.
concepts.unlisted_description: Limited statutory jurisdiction for election petitions.

issues.text: Whether the jurisdiction of civil courts to question the legality of any action taken by or under the authority of the electoral registration officer in including a name in the electoral roll is barred under section 30 of the Representation of the People Act, 1950?

Whether the inclusion of the appellant's name in the electoral roll without complying with the procedure under Rule 26 of the Representation of the People (Preparation of Electoral Rolls) Rules, 1956 is illegal?

anchor.surface_text: Rule 26 of the Representation of the People preparation of Electoral Rolls Rules, 1956, says Every application under sub-section i of section 23 shall be made in duplicate in Form 4 Part 1 and shall be accompanied- a where it is to the chief electoral officer, by a fee of ten rupees, and b where it is to the electoral registration officer, by a fee of one rupee.

issues.text: Whether non-compliance with the procedure prescribed under Rule 26 renders the electoral registration officer's action a nullity?

Whether a person whose name is in the list of voters of the Panchayat constituency is qualified to be elected as a member of the Panchayat under section 10 of the Mysore Village Panchayats and Local Boards Act, 1959 unless disqualified under the Act or any other law?

anchor.surface_text: Section 9 of the Act reads The electoral roll of the Mysore legislative Assembly for the time being in force for such part of the constituency of the Assembly as is included in any Panchayat constituency shall, for the purpose of this Act, be deemed to be the list of voters for such Panchayat constit- uency.

issues.text: Whether the Munsiff's court under section 13(3)(a)(i) of the Mysore Village Panchayats and Local Boards Act, 1959 has jurisdiction to set aside an election on the ground of improper acceptance of nomination where the candidate's name is in the voters list?

Whether the appellant's name was included in the authenticated list of voters published under Rule 3 clause 5 of the Mysore Panchayats and Taluk Boards Election Rules, 1959 on the date fixed for filing nominations?

anchor.surface_text: that on the date, fixed for filing of nominations the appellants name was not in the authenticated list of voters published under r. 3, cl. 5 of the Mysore Panchayats

issues.text: Whether the appellant was ordinarily a resident of Byappanahalli and therefore qualified to stand for election from that constituency?

anchor.surface_text: The case of the first respondent, as disclosed in his petition, was, that on the date, fixed for filing of nominations the appellants name was not in the authenticated list of voters published under r. 3, cl. 5 of the Mysore Panchayats and Tuluk Boards Election Rules, 1959, hereinafter called the Rules, and, therefore, he was not entitled to file his nomination. It was his further case that the appellant was not ordinarily a resident of Byappanahalli and, therefore, he was disqualified from standing for the election from that constituency.

issues.text: Whether, if the election of the appellant was void, the Munsiff could have declared the first respondent to have been duly elected in his place?

It was his further case that the appellant was number ordinarily a resident of Byappanahalli

arguments.claim: Appellant's name included in electoral roll in direct violation of r. 26 of Representation of the People Rules, 1956 and therefore void.

anchor.surface_text: They held that though the name of the appellant was included before- the prescribed date in the electoral roll of the legislative companystituency under s. 23 of the Representation of the People Act, 1950, it was so included in direct violation of r. 26 of the Representation of the People Rules, 1956, arid that, therefore, the said inclusion was void.

arguments.court_reasoning: Illegal but not void/nullity; s.30 bars challenge; voters list final.

arguments.claim: High Court lacked jurisdiction to question legality of inclusion of appellant's name in electoral roll as s.30 Representation of the People Act bars civil courts from questioning ERO actions.

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the appellant Contends that the High Court went wrong in companysidering the question of the legality of the inclusion of the appellants name in the electoral roll of the Mysore Legislative Assembly, as, under s. 30 of the Representations of the People Act, the jurisdiction of civil companyrts to question the legality of an action taken by, or under the authority of, the Electoral Registration Officer was barred.

arguments.claim: First respondent admitted in election petition that appellant's name was included in authenticated list on nomination date.

anchor.surface_text: But a persual of the election petition shows that the first respondent accepted in his petition that the name of the appellant was included in the said authenticated list on the date when be filed his numberination paper.

arguments.claim: No civil court has jurisdiction to question legality of any action taken by or under authority of electoral registration officer per s.30 Representation of the People Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 30 of the Representation of the People Act,1950, numbercivil companyrt shall have jurisdiction to question the legality of any action taken by, or under the authority of, the electoral registration officer.

arguments.claim: Inclusion of name illegal due to non-compliance with r.26 procedure but not a nullity as ERO had jurisdiction; non-compliance does not affect jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: We find it difficult to say that the action of the electoral registration officer is a nullity. He has admittedly jurisdiction to entertain the application for inclusion of the appellants name in the electoral roll and take such action as he deems fit. The number-compliance with the procedure prescribed does number affect his jurisdiction, though it may render his action illegal.

arguments.claim: Voters list is final for purpose of election; person in list qualified to be elected unless disqualified under Act or other law per s.10.

anchor.surface_text: The Act proceeds on the basis that the voters list is final for the purpose of election. Under s. 10 of the Act, every person whose name is in the list of voters of any Panchayat companystituency shall, unless disqualified under this Act or under any other any other law for the time being in force, be qualified to be elected as a member of the Panchayat.

arguments.claim: Munsiff has special jurisdiction under s.13(3) to set aside election only for specified reasons like improper acceptance of nomination; no such improper acceptance as name in voters list and qualified per s.10.

anchor.surface_text: The Act companyfers a special jurisdiction on the Munsif to set aside an election, and he can do so only for the reasons mentioned in s. 13  3  of the Act. The relevant provision is in s. 13- 3   A   d   i  which relates to the improper acceptance of any numberination.

holdings.text: No civil court shall have jurisdiction to question the legality of any action taken by, or under the authority of, the electoral registration officer under s.30 of the Representation of the People Act, 1950.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of clear terms of s.30; action illegal but can only be rectified by appeal or prescribed remedy, not civil court.

holdings.text: The inclusion of the appellant's name in the electoral roll was clearly illegal due to non-compliance with the procedure in r.26 of the Representation of the People (Preparation of Electoral Rolls) Rules, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot, therefore, be denied that the inclusion of the name of the appellant in the electoral was clearly illegal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: ERO did not post application or invite objections as required by r.26.

holdings.text: Non-compliance with r.26 procedure renders the ERO's action illegal but not a nullity, as the officer had jurisdiction to entertain and decide the application.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction to act exists independently of procedural compliance; defect makes action illegal, liable to be set aside only on appeal.

holdings.text: Every person whose name is in the list of voters of any Panchayat constituency shall, unless disqualified under the Act or any other law, be qualified to be elected as a member of the Panchayat under s.10; the voters list is final for election purposes.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory scheme deems Assembly roll as Panchayat voters list and qualifies persons therein unless disqualified; finality for elections.

holdings.text: The Munsiff has special jurisdiction under s.13(3) of the Act to set aside election only for specified reasons including improper acceptance of nomination; no improper acceptance where candidate's name is in voters list and thus qualified under s.10.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Limited statutory grounds; harmonizes s.10 qualification with s.13(3)(a)(i); no power to question voters list validity in election petition.

holdings.text: The appellant's name was included in the authenticated list of voters on the date of filing nomination, as admitted by first respondent in election petition.

anchor.surface_text: But a persual of the election petition shows that the first respondent accepted in his petition that the name of the appellant was included in the said authenticated list on the date when be filed his numberination paper.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct admission in opponent's pleading binds; no need to produce list.

holdings.text: The appellant was ordinarily resident of Byappanahalli and qualified to be in electoral roll.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Munsiff held on the second point that the appellant was ordinarily a resident of the said village and was, therefore, qualified to be included in the electoral roll of the Panchayat,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts lower court finding on evidence; not disturbed on appeal.
